Subject: RE: [junit] Philosophic: Stress Testing with jUnit
Date: Wed, 15 May 2002 10:05:33 +0100
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Internet Mail Service (5.5.2653.19)
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
From: Stuart Moore <smoore@...>
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=112679020

Alexander,
> 
> Does jUnit meet requirements of stress testing? As for me 
> stress testing is testing in conditions which are very close 
> to "production". Is it possible to call such a testing as 
> "unit" testing? In most cases stresstests are to figure out 
> how set of components works, this set may be distributed 
> between server and client, between peers, and so on... but 
> jUnit fundamently works on one machine. I think PRIMARILY 
> jUnit is for testing of classes or small sets of components. 
> Am I right?

I believe you are, however the jperf extension from junit
and the other the ways of running multiple thread / process discussed
recently are aimed at predicting the scalability of your units of code
. However, you are not going to be sure until you do full stress & load 
testing on the production release.

Stu

> PS. there is also difference between load testing and stress 
> testing... above I gathered them under term "stress" :)
> 
>
